intro: Aristeguietia tatamensis, commonly known as the Andean mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant native to the cloud forests of South America. It belongs to the family Loranthaceae and typically grows on the branches of trees such as oaks and pines. The plant has small, oval-shaped leaves and produces white or yellowish flowers that are pollinated by insects. Its berries, which are red and fleshy, are an important food source for birds and other wildlife. Due to habitat loss, Aristeguietia tatamensis is considered threatened and is of interest in botanical research for its ecological and medicinal potential.
